content: If you are a person with your own business, work for yourself and are in the position to realise a business profit or loss, you are considered an SEP.

metadata.content: If you are a person with your own business, work for yourself and are in the position to realise a business profit or loss, you are considered an SEP.

content: All Net Trade Income (NTI)1 declarations for Work Year 2023 (Year of Assessment 2024) can be made with the Inland Revenue Authority of Singapore (IRAS) by filing a tax return. There is no need to file separate declarations with CPF Board. If you receive a notification (via letter/form/SMS) to file tax from IRAS, or you meet the requirement to file tax (i.e. NTI above $6,000 and/or Total Income above $22,000), please complete and submit the tax return to IRAS directly. The income tax filing period is from 1 March to 18 April annually. If you do not receive a notification from IRAS or do not meet the requirement to file tax, you can declare your self-employed net trade income (NTI) to IRAS via myTax Portal which will be available from 1 March to 31 October annually for taxpayers to e-File tax returns. Once IRAS has assessed your income for the year, your assessed NTI will be transmitted to the Board. You can check your updated NTI records by logging in to the Self-employment dashboard with your Singpass.

metadata.header:
Obligations

Declare your Net Trade Income (NTI)

For Work Year 2023 (WY2023) onwards
metadata.content: All Net Trade Income (NTI)1 declarations for Work Year 2023 (Year of Assessment 2024) can be made with the Inland Revenue Authority of Singapore (IRAS) by filing a tax return. There is no need to file separate declarations with CPF Board. If you receive a notification (via letter/form/SMS) to file tax from IRAS, or you meet the requirement to file tax (i.e. NTI above $6,000 and/or Total Income above $22,000), please complete and submit the tax return to IRAS directly. The income tax filing period is from 1 March to 18 April annually. If you do not receive a notification from IRAS or do not meet the requirement to file tax, you can declare your self-employed net trade income (NTI) to IRAS via myTax Portal which will be available from 1 March to 31 October annually for taxpayers to e-File tax returns. Once IRAS has assessed your income for the year, your assessed NTI will be transmitted to the Board. You can check your updated NTI records by logging in to the Self-employment dashboard with your Singpass.

content: If you were not issued a Notice of Assessment (NOA) by IRAS and wish to declare NTI for work years prior to 2023, you can write to us via My Mailbox using your Singpass. If you have declared your NTI with IRAS, you need not declare your income again to the Board. NTI is your gross trade income minus all allowable business expenses, capital allowances and trade losses as determined by IRAS.

metadata.header:
Obligations

Declare your Net Trade Income (NTI)

For Work Year 2022 (WY2022) or earlier
metadata.content: If you were not issued a Notice of Assessment (NOA) by IRAS and wish to declare NTI for work years prior to 2023, you can write to us via My Mailbox using your Singpass. If you have declared your NTI with IRAS, you need not declare your income again to the Board. NTI is your gross trade income minus all allowable business expenses, capital allowances and trade losses as determined by IRAS.

content: Your MediSave contribution is computed based on your age and NTI, as assessed by the IRAS or declared to CPF Board.

metadata.header:
Obligations

Make MediSave contributions

How much to contribute to your MediSave?
metadata.content: Your MediSave contribution is computed based on your age and NTI, as assessed by the IRAS or declared to CPF Board.

content: Your MediSave contribution is due 30 days from the date of issuance of the Notice of Computation from IRAS or Notice of Contribution from CPF Board.

metadata.header:
Obligations

Make MediSave contributions

When to contribute to your MediSave?
metadata.content: Your MediSave contribution is due 30 days from the date of issuance of the Notice of Computation from IRAS or Notice of Contribution from CPF Board.

content: You may sign up to make affordable monthly instalments through GIRO.

metadata.header:
Obligations

Make MediSave contributions

Wish to make MediSave contributions via GIRO?
metadata.content: You may sign up to make affordable monthly instalments through GIRO.

content: You are still required to declare your NTI and make contributions to your MediSave under the Self-Employed Scheme.

metadata.header:
Obligations

For those who are concurrently employees, or have met their Basic Healthcare Sum (BHS)

For self-employed persons who are concurrently employees
metadata.content: You are still required to declare your NTI and make contributions to your MediSave under the Self-Employed Scheme.

content: You are still required to fulfil your mandatory MediSave contributions under the Self-Employed Scheme. Any excess contribution beyond BHS would overflow to: Special Account (SA) (if you are below 55), Retirement Account (RA) (if you are above 55 and do not have Full Retirement Sum [FRS]), Ordinary Account (OA) (if you are aged above 55 and has reached FRS)

metadata.header:
Obligations

For those who are concurrently employees, or have met their Basic Healthcare Sum (BHS)

For self-employed persons who have met their Basic Healthcare Sum (BHS)
metadata.content: You are still required to fulfil your mandatory MediSave contributions under the Self-Employed Scheme. Any excess contribution beyond BHS would overflow to: Special Account (SA) (if you are below 55), Retirement Account (RA) (if you are above 55 and do not have Full Retirement Sum [FRS]), Ordinary Account (OA) (if you are aged above 55 and has reached FRS)

content: Check your eligibility for licence application or renewal (if applicable). If you're an existing self-employed person, you may apply or renew licence(s) (if applicable) when you're up-to-date with your MediSave contributions (paid in full or on an active GIRO plan).

metadata.header:
Other things you can do under the Self-Employed Scheme

Hassle-free licence application/ renewal
metadata.content: Check your eligibility for licence application or renewal (if applicable). If you're an existing self-employed person, you may apply or renew licence(s) (if applicable) when you're up-to-date with your MediSave contributions (paid in full or on an active GIRO plan).

content: You’re encouraged to top up to your MediSave or all 3 CPF accounts (OA, SA, MA), on top of your mandatory contributions, up to a maximum of $37,740 in total.

metadata.header:
Other things you can do under the Self-Employed Scheme

Top up your CPF Savings
metadata.content: You’re encouraged to top up to your MediSave or all 3 CPF accounts (OA, SA, MA), on top of your mandatory contributions, up to a maximum of $37,740 in total.

content: Contribute-As-You-Earn (CAYE) helps SEPs contribute to their MediSave as they earn when their Corporate Service Buyers make payment to them.

metadata.header:
Other things you can do under the Self-Employed Scheme

Ease your MediSave contributions with CAYE
metadata.content: Contribute-As-You-Earn (CAYE) helps SEPs contribute to their MediSave as they earn when their Corporate Service Buyers make payment to them.

content: You can enjoy tax relief on your mandatory and voluntary contributions based on whichever is lower: 37% of assessable income or CPF Annual Limit of $37,740 or Actual amount contributed by you. There is no tax relief for your mandatory or voluntary CPF contributions if your assessed NTI for the year of assessment is zero or negative.

metadata.header:
What additional benefits can you receive as a self-employed person?

Tax relief
metadata.content: You can enjoy tax relief on your mandatory and voluntary contributions based on whichever is lower: 37% of assessable income or CPF Annual Limit of $37,740 or Actual amount contributed by you. There is no tax relief for your mandatory or voluntary CPF contributions if your assessed NTI for the year of assessment is zero or negative.

content: Lower-wage SEPs who earn less than a monthly average NTI of $2,300 may qualify for the Workfare Income Supplement (WIS) scheme.

metadata.header:
What additional benefits can you receive as a self-employed person?

Workfare Income Supplement (WIS)/h4>
metadata.content: Lower-wage SEPs who earn less than a monthly average NTI of $2,300 may qualify for the Workfare Income Supplement (WIS) scheme.

content: SEPs who are part of the Drive and Save (DAS) scheme can receive up to $20 monthly co-contribution.

metadata.header:
What additional benefits can you receive as a self-employed person?

Co-contribution scheme
metadata.content: SEPs who are part of the Drive and Save (DAS) scheme can receive up to $20 monthly co-contribution.
